div1.p: Bridges provides the military record of Roger Post Ames.

div1.head: Memorandum from C.H. Bridges, [19--]
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Ames
COPY
MILITARY RECORD OF ROGER POST AMES
Office of the Adjutant General of the
Army.
div1.p:
The records of my office show that Roger P. Ames served
under contract as Acting Assistant Surgeon, from May 14, 1898,
to November 30, 1898, when his contract was annulled under
honorable conditions. He did not serve outside of the U.S.
under this contract.

He again entered into contract as acting assistant surgeon
April 15, 1898. He reported for duty at Military Hospital No. 1,
Havana, Cuba, April 25, 1898, and was on duty there until April 10,
1900, when he was assigned to Columbia Barracks, Cuba. On
November 20, 1900, he reported for duty at the experimental
Sanitary Camp, near the Barracks, established by the Yellow Fever
Board, under the direction of Major Walter Reed and was assigned
to the Yellow Fever Ward. He appears to have remained on duty
at this camp, which was known as Camp Lazear until Jan. 27,
1901, when he contracted Yellow Fever for which treated until
Feb. 5, 1901 when he returned to duty at Post hospital, Columbia
Barracks, Cuba. His contract was annulled on his acceptance
on April 26, 1901, of an appointment as Captain and Assistant
Surgeon of Volunteers. He was relieved from duty at Columbia
Barracks and ordered to report to the Commanding Officer,
Pirotechnica Militar, Havana, Cuba, at which place he was in duty
from June 15, 1901. He left Cuba Nov. 16, 1901, and arrived
in San Francisco, Cala. Nov. 18, 1901, remaining on duty at
Presidio Hospital, San Francisco, Cala. until Nov. 27, 1901
when granted two months leave of absence. He was appointed
Major and Surgeon of Volunteers Jan. 6, 1902, and was ordered
to Manila P.J., at which place he was present on Feb. 19, 1902.
He reported back to the U.S. March 9, 1902, and remained in the
U. S. on duty at various points until Feb. 1, 1903, when he was
honorably discharged from service.

He again entered the contract as Acting Assistant Surgeon
Feb. 27, 1903, and his contract was annulled under honorable
conditions March 15, 1907. Under this last contract he did not
serve outside of the United States.

closer.signed:
C. H. BRIDGES,
Major General,
The Adjutant General
By: G. W.
